AI-1

14 Nov 2018

One fine Autumn evening, while basking in the sun on my terrace, I came up with a question: Can I teach a computer a simple fact:

â€œBill Clinton is the president of the United States.â€

My goal was to make the computer understand this fact, and ask it followup questions like:

â€œIs Bill Clinton a person?â€,

â€œIs there a place called â€˜the United Statesâ€™?â€,

â€œWho is the president of the United States?â€,

etc.

Being unaware of Alan Turingâ€™s musings on similar topics, or the literature that was around at the time, I started proposing my own ideas on paper:

My goals were to figure out:

  • How to represent meaning of facts,
  • Provide a querying mechanism to ask questions, and
  • Answer the questions from the meaning

Natural Language Parsing

One of the most natural place to go when you find yourself with these questions is Natural Language Processing or NLP, for short. I started looking at Backus Naur Form for computer languages and started building a basic BNF for English.

Computer Semantics and First Order Logic

http://www.coli.uni-saarland.de/projects/milca/courses/comsem/html/index.html

Prolog

http://lpn.swi-prolog.org/lpnpage.php?pageid=online

The meaning of meaning
